intro: Dendrophthoe acacioides var. longifolia, commonly known as the long-leaved parasitic creeper, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches itself to the roots of other plants, primarily acacia species. It belongs to the family Rhamnaceae and is characterized by its slender, woody stems and opposite, lanceolate leaves. The plant produces small, clustered yellowish-green flowers followed by small, fleshy fruits that are dispersed by animals. It is native to southern Africa and thrives in tropical and subtropical regions with well-drained soils. Due to its parasitic nature, it can cause stress to its host plants, making it both ecologically significant and potentially problematic in certain environments.
